title: Dream World
label: AraabMuzik Label Group
description: AraabMuzik’s long-awaited sophomore LP Dream World is packed with more sonic diversity than his beloved debut, Electronic Dream. This works both for and against him.

title: GØGGS
label: In the Red
description: Ty Segall's latest collaboration—with Ex-Cult's Chris Shaw and Fuzz's Charles Moothart—isn't a revolution. They’re just three friends, hellbent on sustaining guitar music’s urgency and simplicity

title: The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill
label: Columbia
description: The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill is a declaration of independence. With it, Ms. Hill put the entire genre of hip-hop on blast and elevated heartbreak to spiritual proportions.

title: Into the Light
label: Chaos Kitchen
description: Guitarist Marisa Anderson's latest album soundtracks a theoretical sci-fi Western of her own invention, where it’s up to the listener to fill in the cinematic details.

title: Summer 08
label: Because Music
description: Metronomy's latest record strips away any pretense that they are a band, focusing on its sole creator, Joe Mount. The album solidifies his own idiosyncratic brand of standoffish funk.

title: Fallen
label: Apron
description: Steven Julien specializes in a jubilantly no-frills strain of house and techno, and his debut album is bare-bones—just gnarled acid sequences, bare-knuckle drum programming, and drifting synths.

title: Live at Third Man Records
label: Third Man
description: Live at Third Man Records* *is the first live album by comedy duo Scharpling & Wurster. It's a concise set that seems focused on celebrating their act, rather than expanding on it.

title: Ellis
label: Erased Tapes
description: Nils Frahm collaborates with fellow composer Woodkid on a ruminative score for a documentary about Ellis Island, narrated by Robert DeNiro.

title: Magma
label: Roadrunner
description: The acclaimed avant-metal outfit Gojira’s sixth full-length LP is their most accessible release yet, melodically immediate and charged with emotion.

title: Wildflower
label: Modular
description: The Avalanches return with their first new album in 16 years.

title: Nite-Funk
label: Glydezone
description: Nite Jewel and Dâm-Funk have been teasing a collaboration for years, and their long-awaited EP, they capture lightning in a bottle. More, please.

title: Streets of Compton
label: Entertainment One
description: The soundtrack to the The Game's three-part documentary series Streets of Compton feels like a missed opportunity for the rapper to embrace his comfort zone.

title: Cheetah
label: Warp
description: The newest Aphex Twin since Richard D. James returned from his extended hiatus shows a simpler side of his music, with slower tempos and spine-tinglingly rich tunes and timbres.

title: Hot Hot Heat
label: Culvert Music
description: After 17 years, five albums, and numerous line up changes, Hot Hot Heat are calling it quits with their final, self-titled LP, which looks back on things with surface cheeriness and tangible fatigue.

title: Paradise Gallows
label: Relapse
description: Paradise Gallows finds the Richmond, Virginia five-piece alternatively aiming to be both the world’s heaviest act and also the prettiest.

title: Biologia Animale E Vegetale
label: Cinedelic
description: The composer Egisto Macchi was part of the same collective that included Ennio Morricone. He scored numerous films and documentaries in Europe: This collection gives shape to his legacy.

title: Weaves
label: Buzz
description: The Toronto indie rock quartet Weaves' self-titled debut is an impressive album about incapacitating infatuation.

title: California
label: Viking Wizard Eyes
description: Blink-182's seventh album wants to be a pop-punk eminence album, evidence humbly submitted that this aging pack of skater brats is still young, selectively dumb, and full of commiserating angst.

title: Primary Colours
label: RCA
description: After scoring a #1 hit with 2014's "Rude,"  the Canadian Rastatryhardians return with an album that posits them as "Magic! The Career Artists."

title: Delirium Tremens
label: Mute
description: Former Bad Seeds sideman Mick Harvey revisits the songbook of Serge Gainbourg for the third time, moving past the salacious icon’s signature songs into his oddities.

title: Alice Bag
label: Don Giovanni
description: Alice Bag was the lead singer and co-founder of the Bags, one of the first punk rock bands to emerge from L.A., and Alice Bag is her first solo record in a 40-year career.

title: Anagrams
label: Melodic
description: Stephen Steinbrink has been bouncing around the West Coast indie underground for over a decade now.  The singer/songwriter's new album is his best, with winsome shades of Elliott Smith's XO.

title: The Bride
label: Parlophone
description: Natasha Khan's latest album as Bat For Lashes is a richly theatrical concept album detailing the story of a woman left at the altar after the husband dies in a car crash on the way to the wedding.

title: Different Class
label: Island
description: On 1995's Different Class, Pulp and Jarvis Cocker were arty outsiders worming their way into the lives of ordinary folk, and they became pop in its most democratically widespread sense.

title: Nice As Fuck
label: Love’s Way
description: The post-punk project Nice As Fuck is the most low-stakes album Jenny Lewis has ever been a part of, but it hits its mark.

title: Dream Music
label: Leaving
description: Dream Music is a reissue of two self-released records from the early ’80s by an obscure New Mexican New Age artist named Jeff Berry. His work, weird and entrancing, sounds remarkably fresh in 2016.

title: New English
label: G.O.O.D. Music
description: 19-year-old Brooklyn rapper Desiigner emerged from nowhere to collaborate with Kanye on The Life of Pablo. On New English, he sounds like the last five years of hip-hop watered down.

title: Uniola
label: Tiny Engines
description: Look Mexico's Uniola is a caffeinated kind of indie rock that works to the rhythm of daily life, while their lyrics treat soul-searching as natural, inescapable part of living.

title: Human Story 3
label: Break World
description: James Ferraro’s latest album feels a bit like a didactic student art project; it finds the vaporwave pioneer doubling down on the themes of 2011’s Far Side Virtual with a much heavier hand.

title: Autodrama
label: Manifesto
description: The L.A. band Puro Instinct evaporates some of the shoegaze fog around their debut for some tentative bigger pop maneuvers.

title: Entities Inertias Faint Beings
label: Room40
description: Composer/performer/improviser David Toop’s latest release traces the seam between sound and music, paying attention to the hidden sounds that surround us and turning silence inside out.

title: Project E.T. Esco Terrestrial
label: Free Bandz
description: Esco Terrestrial is technically DJ Esco’s project, but the weight of it is carried by Future, who appears on all but two songs. Despite strong moments, Future sounds a little exhausted.

title: Freetown Sound
label: Domino
description: Dev Hynes' third album as Blood Orange is a searing and soothing personal document, striking the same resonant chords as Kendrick Lamar’s *To Pimp a Butterfly or *D’Angelo’s Black Messiah.

title: I, Gemini
label: Transgressive
description: The teenaged duo Let's Eat Grandma explore the nightmarish whimsy of nursery rhymes and folktales with a distinctly English flavor on their chilling and impressive debut.

title: Sound in Time
label: Dischord
description: With warped lyrics and a thing for repetition, Lungfish embodied the D.C. area’s post-hardcore innovations. No one else has gotten as weird since.

title: Indigo
label: River Tiber
description: On his debut LP, the Toronto producer and singer/songwriter Tommy Paxton-Beesley, aka River Tiber, sums up the chilly, forlorn pop sound that has defined his city.

title: The Magic
label: Polyvinyl
description: The avant-pop stalwarts return with one of their loosest and most rock-heavy records yet, slightly bending their own rules while remaining stubbornly singular.

title: Going By
label: Double Double Whammy
description: Felix Walworth's second album of indie-pop under the name Told Slant addresses questions of trauma, confusion, and loss with frankness and intimacy.

title: It’s Hard for Me To Say I’m Sorry
label: Editions Mego
description: Christian Fennesz and Jim O'Rourke tease out their differences across two long instrumental tracks that are alternately luminous and blustery.

title: Fire
label: Don Giovanni
description: Amy Klein’s solo debut, after stints as the grinning rhythm guitarist in Titus Andronicus and several other projects, feels like the demo that your college roommate’s band just made.

title: b
label: Trip
description: Bjarki is a closely watched new techno producer from Iceland with a deft touch for big, dumb ragers. On the first of 3 new releases this year, he treats old-school techno with classic-rock reverence.

title: Codex Obscura Nomina
label: Debemur Morti
description: This split LP from Blut Aus Nord and Ævangelist explores black metal’s capacity to accommodate an array of sounds and moods, not just grimness.

title: Otero War
label: Cinematic
description: Like the two Caveman albums before it, Otero War could be an accessory to a generic and fictionalized network-tv retelling of “indie rock in the 2010s.”

title: The Christic Shows, November 16 & 17, 1990
label: Columbia
description: The new entry in Springsteen’s Live Archives series is the most unusual offering so far: two acoustic shows from 1990 that find him alone onstage for the first time since his commercial breakthrough.

title: True Sadness
label: Republic
description: It’s fitting that the Avett Brothers’ most disappointing record yet bears the title of True Sadness. Is this some kind of play for the Top 40, or just instrumental bloat and trite sentiment?

title: Jay II
label: Mint
description: Musician/producer Jay Arner excels at sneaking despondence and alienation into airtight, earwormy pop gems. On Jay II he explores his love of New Wave and other '80s pop.

title: Suicide / Alan Vega Martin Rev
label: Superior Viaduct
description: The godfathers of no wave use bits of punk, post-punk, and disco, connecting them all through attitude. In their first two albums, you can even hear the roots of new wave, industrial, and techno.

title: Yoncalla
label: Cascine
description: Yumi Zouma’s first album closes a longtime distance between its members and delivers bright, complex disco-rock.

title: Muzik
label: PHLEX
description: Several years removed from their turn-of-the-decade peak, Delorean's frothy dance-pop has soured somewhat.

title: Tonight's the Night
label: Reprise
description: Neil Young's Tonight's the Night is a harrowing record about loss and death. Yet it often sounds like a raucous party thrown by a bunch of lovable knuckleheads having the time of their life.

title: The Mountain Will Fall
label: Mass Appeal
description: DJ Shadow trades in his turntables and MPC for a copy of Ableton and embarks upon a freewheeling, low-stakes journey through the contemporary sounds that inspire his practice.

title: Warm Leatherette
label: Island
description: Warm Leatherette, Grace Jones’ career-shifting 1980 release, gives a glimpse of the artist just as her true genius was coming into sharp focus.

title: American Tunes
label: Nonesuch
description: American Tunes is a posthumous album from the legendary musician, songwriter, and New Orleans legend Allen Toussaint, whose smartly funky touch enlivens a selection of standards.

title: John Cage Meets Sun Ra: The Complete Concert
label: Modern Harmonic
description: This live album documents the meeting of two avant-garde legends, but it is not exactly a "super duo." The curious chemistry these two share is subtler and possibly more rewarding than that.

title: Trans Day of Revenge
label: Nervous Nelly
description: The second EP from the queer hardcore punk band G.L.O.S.S. conveys a violent and severe world, one in which the only reasonable and intelligent responses are anger and aggression.

title: The Dreaming Room
label: Sony
description: Laura Mvula is a classically trained vocalist with an orchestral pop style all her own. Her second album is filled with her rich and moving voice and is laden with sonic surprises.

title: Post Plague
label: Telephone Explosion
description: Toronto trio Odonis Odonis forgo their rowdy surf/garage mix for a pulsating, John Carpenter-esque goth palette, while their lyrics explore the dire consequences of unchecked technological progress.

title: Libras
label: Joyful Noise
description: Matthew Friedberger's latest is an instrumental effort with Sebadoh (and sometimes Fiery Furnaces) drummer Bob D’Amico. The best moments have Friedberger's antic playfulness and melodic gift.

title: Moog for Love
label: Island
description: After last year's underwhelming Caracal, the Disclosure brothers' surprise-dropped EP shows that thrill isn’t quite gone, but it’s definitely not the same.

title: Tween
label: Merge
description: Tween is a collection of outtakes from the perennially overlooked Baltimore indie rock band's previous two LPs, yet it manages to capture the full scope of their vision.

title: Secretly Susan
label: Twosyllable
description: Melbourne artist Sui Zhen's world is brilliant and uncanny, and her music explores a familiar theme—the thinness of digital-media life—with a fresh eye.

title: Blood // Sugar // Secs // Traffic
label: Sub Pop
description: The Pittsburgh quartet the Gotobeds trade in the dour, verbose post-punk of bands like Parquet Courts and Protomartyr, with lyrics that suggest they're aware they walk a well-traveled road.

title: Puberty 2
label: Dead Oceans
description: On her fourth album, Mitski makes a resounding personal statement and stakes out her territory as one of the most compelling voices in the sphere of indie rock.

title: Magic 19
label: self-released
description: Bishop Nehru debuted as DOOM's protege and signed and split with Nas' label all before age 19. Now, he stakes out his own territory on a mostly self-produced effort that blasts off for other galaxies.

title: Delayer
label: Magic Bullet
description: RLYR features Pelican guitarist Trevor Shelley de Brauw, Locrian percussionist Steve Hess, and Russian Circles bassist Colin DeKuiper. Their debut is forty minutes of uncommonly optimistic post-rock.

title: Brigid Mae Power
label: Tompkins Square
description: Irish folk singer Brigid Mae Power's latest occupies a liminal space made up of droning guitars, metallic piano reverberations, and lyrics that trace some barely escaped threat.

title: Still Brazy
label: Def Jam
description: Compton rapper YG's follow up to 2014's My Krazy Life parts with DJ Mustard's snaps and dips into rich, classic g-funk, while YG grapples with the contradictions of being a celebrity gangster.

title: The Big Cover-Up
label: Olsen
description: The Norwegian producer's latest EP remixes a handful of strange tunes, from Vangelis to Boney M.  to Yellow Magic Orchestra, that have entered the disco canon.

title: ELDORADO
label: RCA
description: On his debut album, Ro James delivers a pleasant but only sporadically exciting R&B affair.

title: The Glowing Man
label: Young God
description: Swans close their current chapter on a subdued but powerful note.

title: PAGAN
label: Mixpak
description: South London musician Benjy Keating is signed to the acclaimed independent dancehall label Mixpak, where he makes a strange and subdued DIY bedroom-pop version of dancehall.

title: Media in the Service of Terror
label: Hospital Productions
description: In his industrial techno guise Vatican Shadow, Dominick Fernow (aka Prurient) explores some of his most simultaneously bleak and clubby music yet.

title: The Getaway
label: Warner Bros.
description: The Red Hot Chili Peppers' eleventh album is their first since 1989’s Mothers’ Milk without Rick Rubin behind the boards, opting instead for Danger Mouse and Nigel Godrich.

title: Friday Night
label: Merge
description: On his sometimes-hilarious, seat-of-the-pants live concert album, Arcade Fire's Will Butler shows the good and bad sides of winging it and hoping your audience follows.

title: Weval
label: Kompakt
description: With their self-titled debut, Weval have made the rare electronic record that is so strong and obviously appealing that it can't help but end up in the hands of casual listeners.

title: All Things Must Pass
label: Apple
description: Given his own studio, his own canvas, and his own space, George Harrison did what no other solo Beatle did on All Things Must Pass: He changed the terms of what an album could be.

title: A Youthful Dream
label: Fat Possum
description: Aarhus punks Yung take the austere vibe of their big-brother bands like Iceage and shoot it through with some old-fashioned American-fuck-up energy, a la Paul Westerberg and Jay Reatard.

title: Lil B.I.G. Pac
label: Dollaz N Dealz
description: On his best mixtape yet, the Southern rapper offers introspective street rap, free-flowing punchlines, and youthful swagger, moving beyond the Gucci and Boosie comparisons to find a voice of his own.

title: You Will Never Be One of Us
label: Nuclear Blast
description: Nails make music for when you look at life and see little of value, for when you're feeling bitter and alone. On their latest, they make a little room for others to stare at the void with them.

title: case/lang/veirs
label: Anti-
description: The debut from k.d. lang, Neko Case, and Laura Veirs isn’t a springboard or a resting place for any of these vets. It's an exquisite tribute to connection and reflection on the things that bind us.

title: Live at the Witch Trials/Dragnet
label: Superior Viaduct
description: New reissues of the Fall’s first two albums find the band hungry, angry, and taking switchblades to a grim future.

title: Alpha
label: !K7
description: Audion is the minimal-techno guise of Matthew Dear, and often a vent for his most antic impulses. Alpha jettisons the wilder stuff for a sleek, toned-down, crisper affair.

title: On My One
label: Island
description: The pop-star-baiting, credibility-seeking, Noel-Gallagher-approved (and then shunned), surly major label rocker Jake Bugg turns in one of the most baffling collections of music in recent memory.

title: EARTH
label: Reprise
description: Neil Young’s not-exactly-live album EARTH, a set of songs from across his career about food awareness, feels like the first time in a while that Young has been in on his own joke.

title: Last Year Was Complicated
label: Island
description: On Last Year Was Complicated, Nick Jonas follows in the tried-and-true “I'm having sex now, guys” footsteps of boybanders past.

title: Professional Sunflow
label: Superior Viaduct
description: Just as they did with dub icons The Congos, Sun Araw collaborate with New Age icon Laraaji on the hazy, welcoming* Professional Sunflow. *

title: It's Too Late to Stop Now... Volumes II, III, IV & DVD
label: Sony
description: On the newly reissued 1974 live album It's Too Late To Stop Now, Van Morrison discovers his peak as a performer. The band builds an environment; Morrison wanders through all of its available space.

title: Liquid Cool
label: Gloriette
description: After a pop-oriented push on 2012’s One Second of Love, Nite Jewel's Ramona Gonzalez reclaims the murky, DIY vision of her Altered Zones-era releases.

title: Early Recordings
label: Merge
description: Katie Crutchfield's first EP as Waxahatchee, originally released on cassette, unfolds like a pleasant secret on the brink of being passed around.

title: Midnight
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Dan Lissvik's latest solo album echoes his past glory with the Swedish dance-rockers Studio, but teases when it could fulfill.

title: Mandatory Check
label: EMPIRE
description: This Sacramento rapper has had a busy couple of years, and though his latest often sounds rushed, he remains one of the foremost narrative stylists in hip-hop.

title: Turn to Gold
label: Infinity Cat
description: On Diarrhea Planet's third album, arena-rock ambition clashes with D.I.Y. scuzz–and a vocalist coup may be in order.

title: Thick as Thieves
label: Glassnote
description: On their third full-length, the Temper Trap capture some of the crowd-pleasing sound of their debut, unleashing likable enough pop-rock with a bright electronic sheen.

title: Jackie Lynn
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Haley Fohr's newest songwriting persona doesn't mince words–but she also leaves her full potential unknown.

title: Argonautica
label: Firehouse 12
description: The experimental trumpeter Nate Wooley is known for disassembling his instrument and making music from its various parts. Here, he pays homage to one of his mentors with epic, rock-infused tumult.

title: Why Are You OK
label: Interscope
description: Working with producer Jason Lytle, formerly of the band Grandaddy, Ben Bridwell has crafted his best album in nearly a decade, but problems still remain.

title: What One Becomes
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Sumac, Aaron Turner's post-Isis trio, succeed at making minimalist doom metal because they recall what fans of Isis loved without resembling Turner's past work in the slightest.

title: For Those Of You Who Have Never (And Also Those Who Have)
label: Proibito
description: Kansas City producer Huerco S.'s second album is ambient music through and through—though it’s informed by a memory of club music, which hangs over it like a ringing in the ears.

title: Movie!
label: Gronland
description: Holger Czukay left Can in 1978 and began a solo career shortly afterward. His debut solo album, now reissued, reveals an impish, cut-and-paste jester behind Can’s impassive façade.

title: The Digging Remedy
label: Warp
description: Warp Records mainstays Plaid have staked out a well-defined territory over two decades: They make highly listenable melodic IDM, warm and playful. Their latest album doesn't rip up the blueprint.

title: Twentyears
label: Parlophone
description: On Air's first best-of collection, the early hits are all accounted for—but the band's quirks and ambitions get lost in the haze.

title: Hounds of Love
label: EMI
description: With her self-produced fifth album, Kate Bush became a total auteur, embracing the possibilities of digital sampling synthesizers and creating a perfect marriage of technique and exploration.

title: Fall Forever
label: Kanine
description: On their bleak new album, the Brighton band abandons all hints of jangle-pop and dives into extraterrestrial synths, ominously bowed bass, and guitars distorted beyond recognition.

title: Wild Things
label: Polyvinyl
description: After 2012's spiky, lonely, underrated Anxiety, Ladyhawke returns to '80s-inflected synth-pop on Wild Things.

title: Fantasma
label: Lefse
description: Cornelius's Fantasma was a high point of the mid-'90s Shibuya-kei scene, an eclectic crate-diggers' subgenre that celebrated old sounds. Its vinyl reissue shows it still sounds fresh in 2016.

title: Piano
label: Moshi Moshi
description: The Hot Chip frontman's third solo record is his most straightforward and surprisingly personal effort, a collection of songs for just piano and voice.

title: Strange Little Birds
label: STUNVOLUME
description: With their post-return jitters under control, Garbage have solidified that return with Strange Little Birds, their darkest, most intimate LP and the band’s strongest effort in 15 years.

title: Emotions and Math
label: ATO
description: Singer/songwriter Margaret Glaspy's Emotions and Math is a collection of compact grunge-rock and breezy torch songs that variously recall Elliott Smith and Joni Mitchell.

title: Victorious
label: M-Plant
description: Detroit techno legend Robert Hood, under his Floorplan alias, invites his teenage daughter Lyric to coproduce Victorious, which is more open, more anthemic, and brighter than much of his past work.

title: Foiled Again
label: Carpark
description: Speedy Ortiz's latest EP features two unreleased tracks from Foil Deer as well as two remixes of “Puffer,” one featuring a verse from rapper Lizzo and one by Open Mike Eagle.

title: The Other Side of the River
label: Future Days
description: Terry Reid turned down offers to front Led Zeppelin and recorded some flawless folk-rock albums but never escaped obscurity. This comprehensive reissue rounds out his untold story.

title: There’s Alot Going On
label: Roc Nation
description: On his new EP, Vic Mensa opens up like never before, airing his mistakes and fears.

title: Stranger to Stranger
label: Concord
description: Stranger to Stranger is arguably the best album of Paul Simon's uneven post-Graceland solo career. His reliably melodic songwriting is buoyed by his most adventurous arrangements in years.

title: Breakin’ Point
label: Ingrid
description: Breakin’ Point, PB&J's sixth album, enlists big-name producers like Paul Epworth, Greg Kurstin, and Emile Haynie. The result is the big pop album they've always seemed on the verge of making.

title: Black Terry Cat
label: Anti-
description: On her second album, Xenia Rubinos negotiates a world that has prescribed ideas about how she should be—particularly as a person of color—and incisively questions her place outside of those roles.

title: Blonde on Blonde Revisited
label: Mojo
description: For the album's fiftieth birthday, an impressive roster of artists, from Steve Gunn to Marissa Nadler to Jim O'Rourke, pay tribute to Dylan's Blonde on Blonde.

title: Ha, Ha, He.
label: Captured Tracks
description: With its two-tone album cover, terse songwriting, and Albini-style, hands-off recording, *Ha, Ha, He. is Mourn's *period piece, conjuring the grave austerity of mid-'90s post-punk.

title: Love You to Death
label: Warner Bros.
description: After going synth-pop on 2013's Heartthrob, Tegan and Sara team up once again with super-producer Greg Kurstin for the follow up. At their best, they boil love songs down to their aching essence.

title: Ash & Ice
label: Domino
description: Ash & Ice is The Kills’ first album in five years and they encompass everything they’ve done before, as well as bringing in boombox beats with Brazilian and Afro-pop influences.

title: Future Present Past EP
label: Cult
description: On their newest EP, The Strokes continue to perform “The Strokes” for a new generation of younger and casual listeners.

title: It Came From N.Y.C.
label: Numero Group
description: They may have found fame through Beavis and Butt-Head, but in their early days, White Zombie operated in the same NYC underground as Swans and Sonic Youth. This Numero Group box set tells the story.

title: Levitate
label: R&S
description: At its best, this short, punchy album feels like a distillation of everything that has made British producer Lone's work great so far.

title: Masterpiece
label: Saddle Creek
description: On the rangy folk-rock band Big Thief's Saddle Creek debut Masterpiece, the songs sound cherry-picked over a lifetime of writing, the stories carefully compiled.

title: Big Bossin Vol. 1
label: self-released
description: On Big Bossin Vol. 1, Detroit underground hero and Texas-based producer Cardo Got Wings work together to make a smooth, technicolor tribute to classic LA gangster rap.

title: My Best Human Face
label: Jagjaguwar
description: After two records of quiet, lonely, piano-only music, Spencer Krug returns to the guitars, bleeping synths, and pounding rhythms of his best-loved work.

title: Basses Loaded
label: Ipecac
description: Perhaps for the first time ever, the Melvins sound unfocused and—worse—like their music is beginning to lack energy.

title: Light Upon the Lake
label: Secretly Canadian
description: On their winsome debut, the duo Whitney make a warm, simple and profoundly enjoyable rock'n'roll record, evoking the earnestness and innocence of Girls.

title: Still They Pray
label: Relapse
description: The new album from Cough could have arrived anytime during, say, the last three decades and placed the Richmond doom metal quartet alongside the ranks of Candlemass or Cathedral, Sleep or Saint Vitus.

title: The Fan-Tas-Tic Box Set
label: Ne'Astra Music Group
description: With the *Fan-Tas-Tic: A Jay-Dee Production *box set, we're given the most concise and thorough presentation ever of the formative years of Slum Village, the group that counted J Dilla in its ranks.

title: Eyes on the Lines
label: Matador
description: Folk-rocker Steve Gunn's latest album is a rich and amiable meditation about travel and transition, about exploring, wandering, and letting yourself get lost.

title: The Wailing Wailers
label: Yep Roc
description: Not only does The Wailing Wailers highlight the first major recordings of Bob Marley, but the happy, bouncy, optimistic sound is also the sound of post-independence Jamaica.

label: Epic
description: On their new album, Fifth Harmony are at their best when grappling with the age-old girl-group concern of how to reconcile independence with love.

title: Collapse
label: Leaving
description: *Collapse *is a strange and beautiful record that refuses categorization, traipsing through the fields of house, free jazz and musique concrète on the way to something inscrutably Other.

title: DJ-Kicks
label: !K7
description: West Coast groove aficionado Dâm-Funk offers an engrossing selection of tracks that are as dreamy as they are funky in his installment of the DJ-Kicks mix series.

title: iiiDrops
label: self-released
description: Joey Purp is a member of Chance the Rapper’s Savemoney Crew, and iiiDrops is his most well-rounded and definitive effort: He comes off as boastful and thoughtful, socially aware and defiantly filthy.

title: Skin
label: Transgressive
description: The young Australian DJ/Producer's profile has grown immensely in the past few years. On his new album, he recruits an all-star cast including Beck, Little Dragon, Vince Staples, and more.

title: Awkward Pop Songs
label: Creep
description: At their best, the Philly punk band JANK highlights the connection between emo’s fourth wave and the unconventional, genre-spanning pop of the Dismemberment Plan or the Unicorns.

title: Modern Country
label: Merge
description: Guitarist William Tyler returns backed by an all-star band that notably includes Wilco’s Glenn Kotche and Megafaun’s Phil Cook, summoning a wide range of moods and telling stories without vocals.

title: Suck on This
label: ZEF
description: Suck on This is a teaser for an upcoming full-length from the South African rap trio, but more often than not these days, Die Antwoord comes off as tired and trying way too hard.

title: Folding Time
label: Hotflush
description: Nearly five years after their debut marked the peak convergence of late-2000s bass music and its myriad influences—dubstep, R&B, footwork, house, ambient, hardcore—Sepalcure return with a second album.

title: Congrats
label: Innovative Leisure
description: The instrumental act's latest album finds them revisiting their circa-05 roots, offering tracks that are as pummeling as they are danceable.

title: Angry Angles
label: Goner
description: Angry Angles captured legendary Memphis garage-rock wildman Jay Reatard in between projects and on the brink of his solo career.

title: Mark Kozelek Sings Favorites
label: Caldo Verde
description: On Mark Kozelek Sings Favorites, the Sun Kil Moon singer offers piano-and-voice interpretations of songs ranging from Modest Mouse's “Float On” to “Send in the Clowns.”

title: Rock the Fuck on Forever
label: Pop Wig
description: Baltimore melodic hardcore band Angel Du$t describe themselves as a mix of the Bad Brains and the Lemonheads, and their latest mixes mash notes with double-time tempos.

title: Mosey
label: New West
description: Ontario musician Daniel Romano's fifth solo full-length finds him relying on classic country flourishes to build simple songs that look to the great beyond.

title: Minor Victories
label: Fat Possum
description: Minor Victories includes members of Mogwai, Editors, and Slowdive, and their self-titled debut is a mix of sighing shoegaze, cinematic wanderlust, and gloomy riffage.

title: Murder for Hire 2
label: Bread Winners’ Association
description: Only four months after his exceptional major label debut Islah, Baton Rouge rapper Kevin Gates returns with a mixtape that plays like a compilation of B-sides or outtakes from the Islah sessions.

title: Kidsticks
label: Anti-
description: Written and produced in Los Angeles with Andrew Hung of Fuck Buttons, Beth Orton's latest is anxious, playful, and sounds little like anything the singer/songwriter has done before.

title: Mondo Alterado
label: Hippie Dance
description: The Mexican techno producer Rebolledo specializes in work that feels hollowed out and slightly creepy, with a sly streak of absurdist humor.

title: X-Communicate
label: Sub Pop
description: In her latest transformation, Kristin Welchez leaves behind Dee Dee and the Dum Dum Girls for new alter ego Kristin Kontrol, foregoing DDG's garage-band cool for sleek synth pop.

title: Tempo
label: One Little Indian
description: Composer Olga Bell's Tempo resembles dance music as glimpsed through a funhouse mirror: strangely distorted, sometimes goofy, and deeply pleasing on a simple, almost childlike level.

title: The Dream is Over
label: SideOneDummy
description: PUP's second album is a glorious half-hour of redlining guitars and pile-on group chants that turn self-loathing and self-deprecation into a sort of superpower.

title: K.M.T.
label: Soul Jazz
description: Whether as the Sun God, I.B.M., IAMTHATIAM, or most often as Hieroglyphic Being, Jamal Moss' discography is filled u-turns; Africans With Mainframes swings into Chicago acid house at its most caustic.

title: Everything's Beautiful / Miles Ahead OST
label: Columbia
description: Messing with Miles Davis music is a dangerous proposition. It was necessary for Don Cheadle's  biopic Miles Ahead, and with help from Robert Glasper, it's sometimes a successful endeavor.

title: elseq 1-5
label: Warp
description: Autechre have surprise-released nearly four hours of music, spanning five volumes. It is the IDM equivalent of a Netflix series binge, and it posits the duo as a sort of post-human jam band.

title: Faraway Reach
label: Innovative Leisure
description: On their latest, tropical-house duo Classixx enlist guest vocalists from How to Dress Well to Passion Pit's Michael Angelakos to T-Pain.

title: It Happened in Flatbush
label: self-released
description: It Happened in Flatbush is a flat album in every way, filled with mealy-mouthed hooks and uninspired tropes—a spiritless effort from a NYC rap group that initially seemed novel in a post-TDE scene.

title: Goodness
label: Tiny Engines
description: On their latter-day emo classic Home, Like NoPlace Is There, the Hotelier took excruciating stock of the darkness. On their newest, the band is pushing with white-hot intensity toward the light.

title: The Last Word on First Blues
label: Omnivore
description: Producer Pat Thomas's loving Last Word on *First Blues *reissue reveals Allen Ginsberg as a missing link in the East Village's musical pathways, a secret alt-folk hero hidden in relatively plain view.

title: Ere Gobez
label: FPE
description: The Ethiopian 11-piece band's sophomore effort is a big, brave roar of an album, reaching and surpassing the heights of their excellent 2012 self-titled debut.

title: Earrings Off!
label: Tri Angle
description: The British experimental rock group Adult Jazz tackle themes of gender and the body's changing place in society on their sophomore outing.

title: Wake Up You!: The Rise & Fall of Nigerian Rock 1972-1977
label: Now Again
description: Wake Up You! specifically covers the short-lived but influential period of Nigerian rock in the country’s post-Civil War era (after 1970).

title: EP 4
label: Wolf Parade Productions
description: On their first EP of new material in six years, Wolf Parade aren't asserting themselves to the world so much as reintroducing themselves to each other.

title: Taste/Should I Remain Here at Sea?
label: Manqué
description: On their two new albums, Islands explore two sides of their personality: the largely electronic Taste is bitter and sharp-witted, while Should I Remain Here at Sea? is more freewheeling.

title: Four Organs / Phase Patterns
label: Superior Viaduct
description: Four Organs and Phase Patterns come from a time when minimalist composer Steve Reich was in an obsessively scientific mode. They establish a new language, while arguing for their very right to exist.

title: Good Luck and Do Your Best
label: City Slang
description: Gold Panda's warm and exuberant new album sounds quite unlike any of the electronic music being made in 2016, and is refreshingly unfashionable in that way.

title: Dangerous Woman
label: Republic
description: Ariana Grande’s third album finds the 22-year-old pop star embracing a Sasha Fierce-like alter ego, with the help of Future, Nicki Minaj, Lil Wayne, Macy Gray, and others.

title: Put the Kid on the Sleepy Horse
label: Topshelf
description: Cult favorites Mock Orange return with an eighth album that reconciles their later alt-country leanings with their Midwestern emo roots.

title: Infrared
label: Fade to Mind
description: On her split EP with the producer Kingdom, Dawn Richard offers a diorama for love’s life cycle, encompassing everything from death defying adoration and righteous anger to, best of all, forgiveness.

title: Changesonebowie
label: Parlophone
description: The original David Bowie hits compilation tells the story of Bowie's metamorphosis from quizzical folkie to a conquering colossus, and is partially responsible for cementing his stardom.

title: Juarez
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: An outlier on the outlaw country scene of the 1970s, Terry Allen's Juarez is a bawdy song cycle that alludes to the fall of the Aztec Empire, Jesus, and motel sex. It retains its kick 40 years on.

title: Kamikaze
label: Votiv
description: The latest record from the So So Glos is driven by the tension between the band’s perennially youthful sound and their ever-more-jaded worldview.

title: Wave
label: Dial
description: The German musician Christian Naujoks makes pensive, idiosyncratic pieces somewhere between electronic and chamber music, and his new album is his most exquisitely melancholy work yet.

title: The Triad
label: Rough Trade
description: The Triad, Pantha du Prince’s first solo record in six years, is the producer's most maximalist and emotional release to date.

title: Pythagorean Dream
label: Foom
description: The pioneering composer and guitarist's latest album *Pythagorean Dream *is a simultaneously giddy and calm mix of the high-minded and the lizard-brained.

title: Fallen Angels
label: Columbia
description: Following on last year's Frank Sinatra tribute Shadows in the Night, Dylan's latest finds him once again putting his own idiosyncratic spin on a set of standards.

title: Ullages
label: Partisan
description: Their debut LP vented disillusionment with hard-charging punk and shouted choruses, but on their followup, the Leeds band channel their misery through a soft-focus dream-pop shimmer.

title: Andando el Tiempo
label: ECM
description: At 80 years old, Carla Bley remains a vital force as a pianist, composer, and improviser, mixing knowingly wry moments with a sense of mystery.

title: Strangers
label: Sacred Bones
description: On her latest gothic folk missive, singer/songwriter Marissa Nadler opens up her sound slightly, retaining her grey-skies aesthetic while bringing in a more spacious and rock-oriented sound.

title: These People
label: Cooking Vinyl
description: The former Verve frontman returns after a hiatus with another Richard Ashcroft solo album, with all the ostentatious orchestration, bumper-sticker mantras, and cursory electro-dabbling those entail.

title: Beyond the Bloodhounds
label: Canvasback / Atlantic
description: Through muscular, chugging guitars and plodding percussion, Nashville's Adia Victoria explores ugly emotional realities with "take it or leave it" boldness.

title: Teens of Denial
label: Matador
description: On Car Seat Headrest's first proper new album for Matador, frontman Will Toledo reaffirms that he is ahead of the pack as an imaginative singer-songwriter, capable of crafting dynamic indie rock.

title: A New Wave of Violence
label: Vice
description: Head Wound City, a supergroup drawing from members of the Blood Brothers, the Locust and the Yeah Yeah Yeahs, convene for an album of abrasive, low-stakes hardcore.

title: August 26th
label: self-released
description: Post Malone is a rap charlatan for the digital age, and his debut mixtape August 26th is like falling down an acoustic rap cover k-hole.

title: In Glendale
label: Rado
description: Tim Heidecker (of Tim & Eric) has released a slick rock record that is also a comedy album, and it is full of all the nervous laughs and queasy vibes of his surrealist comedy.

title: Skip a Sinking Stone
label: Mom & Pop
description: Mutual Benefit's Skip a Sinking Stone, a gorgeous collection of orchestral folk, focuses on the carefully plotted tours of a newly successful band and frontman Jordan Lee's adopted home of New York.

title: Day of the Dead
label: 4AD
description: This epic compilation produced by the National’s Bryce and Aaron Dessner serves as both a fine showcase of the Dead's iconic songs and a who's who of current indie rock.

title: Union and Return
label: Mexican Summer
description: A composer or a jokester? On his fourth album, Luke Wyatt's Torn Hawk project begins to emerge as the medium for a musician interested in pushing the limits of both.

title: Cut and Paste
label: Wichita
description: On his hooky, appealing debut album, the young Londoner Oscar Scheller makes blown-out indie jams with magnetic melodies and an obvious British lineage.

title: Tired of Tomorrow
label: Relapse
description: The Philadelphia band Nothing make gentle-sounding, springtime shoegaze with an alt-pop tinge that would seem all at odds with their gritty punk and hardcore pasts—until you listen to the lyrics.

title: Pile
label: Merge
description: Everything on the surface of A Giant Dog's Merge debut screams beware. From the violent lyrics to the grotesque cover art to the very name of the band, the message is clear.

title: Oh No
label: Hyperdub
description: Jessy Lanza's latest is a gorgeous and deadly pop music manifesto, full of pent-up nervous energy set to release.

title: What Follows
label: DFA
description: DFA vets Shit Robot return, and make their case as the label's long-underrated house band. Featuring guest spots from Alex Taylor, Nancy Whang, and the Juan Maclean.

title: Coloring Book
label: Unknown
description: Chance the Rapper's Coloring Book is one of the strongest rap albums released this year, an uplifting mix of spiritual and grounded that even an atheist can catch the Spirit to.

title: Happy Songs for Happy Zombies
label: Club AC30
description: Frequently pointed to as an underrated shoegaze gem, the debut EP by Pinkshinyultrablast provides an enjoyable (if brief) introduction to the band’s rapturous take on rock.

title: Full of It
label: Kill Rock Stars
description: Recent Kill Rock Stars signees Summer Cannibals expertly balance flame-belching Mad Max riffage with lyrics frankly exploring questions of codependence and need.

title: Fool
label: Brainfeeder
description: Fool is a playfully left-field electronic-jazz hybrid from Dutch artist Mitchel Van Dinther. It bursts at the seams with ideas, and at its best recalls the free spirit of late '90s electronic music.

title: I Hear You
label: Sub Pop
description: The Georgia post-punk band Arbor Labor Union are veterans of various punk and hardcore bands, and on their new album they expand on the rootsy drone of their first.

title: Holy Ghost
label: Run for Cover
description: Modern Baseball's Holy Ghost asks for difficult things out of its audience—space, patience and acceptance—but demonstrates them as a band with an undeniable sonic ambition and social conscience.

title: The Complete Prestige 10-Inch LP Collection
label: Prestige
description: The Complete Prestige 10-Inch LP Collection finds Miles Davis on a search for self, a search for a sound, a search for an aesthetic, a search for like minds.

title: Venus on Edge
label: Daps
description: On their fourth album, Hooded Fang slip away from their garage rock and indie-pop pasts and embrace a weirder, more wired sci-fi horror vision.

title: Nattesferd
label: Roadrunner
description: The Norwegian metal band Kvelertak find the unlikely meeting spot between black metal blast beats and the anthemic power of Van Halen and Judas Priest.

title: Bloom Forever
label: Stolen Recordings
description: In 2014, Peaches Geldof was found dead at 25, the result of a heroin overdose. After a few lost months, her husband Thomas Cohen finished a '70s singer/songwriter record about his wife and children.

title: Heartbreaker (Deluxe Reissue)
label: Pax-Am
description: The deluxe reissue of Ryan Adams' most beloved solo album highlights that what we loved most about this album isn't misery; it is nostalgia, and fondness for an earlier version of ourselves.

title: Konnichiwa
label: Boy Better Know
description: On Skepta's long-awaited new album, the grime pioneer is full of sneering contempt for popular culture’s industry of image, the press, the police, and the government at large.

title: The Heart Speaks in Whispers
label: Virgin
description: Corinne Bailey Rae's lush new album features Esperanza Spalding, Moses Sumney, R&B group KING, and others. The mood feels wide open, centered on spacious grooves.

title: Under the Sun
label: Warp
description: UK producer Mark Pritchard's Under the Sun is deeply atmospheric and richly impressionistic. Key vocal features from Thom Yorke, Linda Perhacs, Bibio, and others give the album its sense of movement.

label: XL
description: The excellent debut of Soundcloud superstar Kaytranada features many collaborators (Syd! Anderson .Paak!) and many drums. He excels at chopping samples, but his colorful sound is never derivative.

title: Down in Heaven
label: Grand Jury
description: The Chicago rock band turns in a casual, charmingly low-key set of kitchen-table blues, slow-dance serenades, and unplugged power pop.

label: Big Crown
description: Covering 50 Cent, Cat Stevens, Faith Evans, and more on steelpan drums should not sound this gimmick-less. It helps that the Bacao Rhythm & Steel Band is, first and foremost, a strong funk ensemble.

title: Bottomless Pit
label: Harvest
description: On their new album Bottomless Pit, Death Grips stitch together one of their most cohesive grotesques, renewing their focus on songcraft.

title: Get Gone
label: Fat Possum
description: In their mix of soulful grease and punky grit, Seratones feel like a natural, rollicking complement to The Alabama Shakes.

title: Electronica 2: The Heart of Noise
label: Columbia
description: Electronic music pioneer Jean-Michel Jarre's latest album features guest spots from The Pet Shop Boys, Primal Scream, Cyndi Lauper, and...Edward Snowden.

title: Get In
label: Editions Mego
description: Austrian producer and Mego labelhead Peter Rehberg is a pioneer of laptop music that's at turns abrasive and sublime. His first release as Pita since 2004 is defined by shifts in volume and intensity.

title: A Moon Shaped Pool
label: XL
description: With their ninth studio album, Radiohead move beyond the existential angst that made them music’s preeminent doomsayers, pursuing a more personal—and eternal—form of enlightenment.

title: The Things That We Are Made Of
label: Lambent Light
description: Mary Chapin Carpenter's lean and haunting songs often sound best when they're given room to breathe. The production here by David Cobb (Jason Isbell, Sturgill Simpson) is just the ticket.

title: Spiritual Songs for Lovers to Sing
label: Mute
description: Former WU LYF frontman Ellery Roberts returns with LUH, his new project with visual artist Ebony Hoorn. Produced by the Haxan Cloak, their debut is a vast, swaggering colossus.

title: Take Me to the Alley
label: Blue Note
description: Grammy winning jazz singer Gregory Porter shone on the Disclosure single, "Holding On." But he's got a big career of his own outside of the British brothers. His new album is sweet and serene.

title: Cult Following
label: Merge
description: Laurel Sprengelmeyer's Cult Following is a flowing record with guests including Sufjan Stevens, Sharon Van Etten, the National’s Dessner brothers, and TV on the Radio’s Kyp Malone.

title: The Colour in Anything
label: Interscope
description: Clocking in at 76 minutes, The Colour in Anything is James Blake’s wonderfully messy dive into maximalism.

title: Kindness for Weakness
label: Stones Throw
description: The usually-vitriolic indie rapper finds a sense of peace on his sixth studio album, which largely trades in frenetic rhymes for introspective narratives.

title: For Good
label: Totally Gross National Product
description: The first Fog record in almost a decade finds Andrew Broder distilling years of genre-hopping down to a core aesthetic. This is Fog in its purest form: minimal, haunting and darkly impressionistic.

title: In Movement
label: ECM
description: Drummer and jazz legend Jack DeJohnette pairs up with saxophonist Ravi Coltrane and bassist (and electronics whiz) Matthew Garrison, to spellbinding and haunting results.

title: As If Apart
label: Captured Tracks
description: Chris Cohen's warm, homespun albums are welcome throwbacks to introspective '70s singer/songwriter LPs. His latest is touched by the sting of loss.

title: Piatto D'Oro
label: Fool's Gold
description: Queens rapper Meyhem Lauren is a devoted student of NYC '90s rap, and on his latest, he pitches himself as a veteran crime boss too deep in the game to change his ways.

title: Island Universe Story: Selected Works
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: Island University Story: Selected Works is a condensed version of a three-cassette series that acts as a shadow narrative of Helado Negro's catalog, offering a gratifying variety of sounds and styles.

title: Will
label: Dead Oceans
description: Julianna Barwick's Will is a looser, less polished album than Nepenthe, and that rough-around-the-edges intimacy turns out to be a great part of its charm.

title: Cluster: 1971-1981
label: Bureau B
description: Exploratory yet grounded, futuristic yet melodic, alien and charming, Cluster were among the best krautrock bands ever. This no-frills box set traces their heavenly horizon-to-horizon arc.

title: Beloved
label: Good Cheer
description: Like drawing a perfect circle, making a good power-pop record is an elusive task. Portland's Mo Troper come closer than many have in awhile, with snot-nosed charm.

title: songs from wonder.land
label: Parlophone
description: songs from wonder.land is a theatrical adaptation of Alice in Wonderland set in an MMORPG, and the score is written by Damon Albarn.

title: Luck or Magic
label: Double Feature
description: Britta Phillips' first solo album, post-Luna and post-Dean & Britta, relies heavily on covers, including one of Stevie Nicks' "Landslide."

title: Terminal Redux
label: Earache
description: Terminal Redux, from the Philadelphia outfit Vektor, is one of the most thrilling, forward-thinking metal albums of the year.

title: Another Splash of Colour - New Psychedelia in Britain 1980-1985
label: Cherry Red
description: Originally released as a 13-track LP in 1981, this compilation documents the fruits of New Psychedelia, which set the scene for glammy Britpop, nerdy twee pop, playful college rock, and more.

title: Trágame Tierra
label: Masters of Bates
description: On his second Big Black Delta LP, Jonathan Bates delivers a maximalist take on electro-pop. On these far-reaching songs, it feels like he’s coloring with every crayon in the box, just because he can.

title: Paradise
label: Domino
description: White Lung's newest is more outspoken, more anthemic than 2014's Deep Fantasy, and frontwoman Mish Barber-Way offers provocative challenges to the idea of what it means to be a Good Feminist.

title: White Hot Moon
label: Run for Cover
description: Drawing from emo, pop-punk and '90s alt-rock, Pity Sex trawl the messy depths of failing romances. White Hot Moon follows the course the band set on 2013’s Feast of Love, with a few deviations.

title: Junjo Presents: Wins the World Cup
label: Greensleeves
description: This reissue of a 1982 dub reggae favorite tells a good story, exemplifies a particular moment in Jamaican music history, and offers a new way to hear how dub reggae works.

title: Guided Meditation
label: Lame-O
description: Philly band Hurry's new LP is pure power pop in the vein of the Posies and Matthew Sweet, revealing a band that is serious about its frivolity.

title: HOPELESSNESS
label: Rough Trade
description: On the crushing and glorious HOPELESSNESS, Anohni collaborates with Hudson Mohawke and OPN to create something new: the electronic dance anthem as visceral protest song.

title: Nonagon Infinity
label: ATO
description: Besides being a killer garage rock album*, Nonagon Infinity *is constructed as an infinite loop, meaning its final notes connect perfectly with the album’s opening.

title: Blue Wave
label: Last Gang
description: Blue Wave is the sound of Dan Boeckner and his latest band discovering the secret ingredient missing from so much of the music meant to reawaken the new wave sound of the 1980s: paranoia.

title: The Impossible Kid
label: Rhymesayers
description: Aesop Rock's second album on Rhymesayers and his first in several years is the most specific he has ever been about what he’s thinking or feeling.

title: Egyptian Lover 1983-1988
label: Stones Throw
description: Stones Throw's new anthology documents how pioneering hip-hop artist Egyptian Lover paved the way for acts like N.W.A. and stretched hip-hop into more experimental territory.

title: Crime Cutz
label: DFA
description: Holy Ghost!'s first new music in years is a bright, tight, tense mini-epic, solidifying the band as one of the pillars of the mid-'00s disco resurgence.

title: Honey
label: Rinse
description: The best songs on Katy B's new album show her caught up in the flow of something so overwhelming she can’t see the beginning or the end of it, time expanding and collapsing with her in its center.

title: Close To the Noise Floor - Formative UK Electronica 1975 - 1984
label: Cherry Red
description: This 4xCD box draws on electro-punk, industrial, synthpop, dark ambient, and more, including key early tracks from the Human League, Throbbing Gristle, and Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark.

title: Testarossa
label: Joyful Noise
description: Testarossa, the second-full length collaboration between Serengeti and WHY?’s Yoni Wolf, shows the rapper born David Cohn finding beauty and life in life's smallest details, as usual.

title: Origami
label: 4AD
description: This five-record retrospective box reminds us that while Lush might not have lunged for the jugular like My Bloody Valentine or Jesus and Mary Chain, they were a first-rate shoegaze band.

title: The Feminine: Act I
label: self-released
description: Frequent Kendrick Lamar collaborator Anna Wise's The Feminine: Act I boldly presents the plight of the everyday woman. If it's corny at times, it's clever at others. Those triumphs make it worthwhile.

title: Modernists
label: Cantaloupe
description: As modern music moves beyond modernism, the classical community is still scared of the innovations of 75 years ago. Alarm Will Sound tackles those scary sounds and finds new life.

title: DJ Koze Presents Pampa Vol. 1
label: Pampa
description: DJ Koze is a big figure in electronic music, but he also appears to be its benevolent godfather. This compilation of tunes from his label Pampa runs the gamut of sounds, but always stays jubilant.

title: VIEWS
label: Cash Money
description: Drake's fourth proper album feels claustrophobic and too long and weirdly monotone, but the occasional tweaks in sound lead to a few great moments.

title: Diamonds and Pearls
label: Warner Bros.
description: By 1991, Prince's unsurpassed run of brilliance had ended, but he still had a lot of great music in him. Diamonds and Pearls had a clutch of future classics along with some odd experiments.

title: Sign o’ the Times
label: Paisley Park
description: Choosing a single high point from Prince’s glorious run in the ’80s is impossible, but Sign o’ the Times surely stands as his most complex and varied statement.

label: Warner Bros.
description: 1999 is the greatest album ever made about partying as a way of staring down oblivion. At the height of the Cold War, suddenly the world felt a little warmer.

title: Parade
label: Paisley Park
description: With "Kiss" as its lead single, Parade reeled in listeners. The rest of the album featured fresh turns of minimalist funk. Prince isn't known for his subtlety, but Parade proves perhaps he should be.

title: Controversy
label: Warner Bros.
description: Controversy emerged in 1981 at a pivotal time not just for Prince, but for America. It's often regarded as a bridge between Dirty Mind and 1999, but it's fascinating record in its own right.

title: Dirty Mind
label: Warner Bros.
description: Prince’s first fully actualized album is an unrelenting dance party, its kinky ambiguities blurring lines between genres and genders and pretty much everything else.

title: Purple Rain
label: Warner Bros.
description: Purple Rain was a landmark that solidified Prince’s standing as the preeminent pop genius of his generation; more than three decades on, it still retains all of its power.

title: Around the World in a Day
label: Warner Bros.
description: After he conquered the world with Purple Rain, Prince made a hard left turn into bright and sweet psychedelia. But the album had more going on beneath the surface.

title: All Jokes Aside
label: self-released
description: Dej Loaf is the rap equivalent of a well-executed eye roll—simple, excellent viciousness. All Jokes Aside is a record full of nonchalant barbs. Men and/or those messing with her money: watch out.

title: Nocturnal Koreans
label: Pinkflag
description: This eight-song mini-LP from the veteran post-punks includes tracks that didn’t fit on their self-titled 2015 album and is marked by an unsettling, dead-of-night calm.

title: Asphalt for Eden
label: Profound Lore
description: The subversive indie hip-hop outfit Dälek return from a hiatus with a revamped lineup and a newfound confidence and profundity.

title: Interventions
label: Northern Spy
description: On their third full-length, Baltimore drone-rockers Horse Lords prove the rewards of "difficult" music.

title: Triangle
label: SusannaSonata
description: After a wide variety of projects and releases, Norwegian singer-songwriter Susanna Wallumrød returns with a grim and often stirring extended meditation on religion and mortality.

title: The Ship
label: Warp
description: The Ship, Eno's sixth album for Warp, is one of his best solo albums in a while, walking the line between pure ambiance and vocal-driven pop.

title: Balter / Saunier
label: New Amsterdam
description: Avant-rockers Deerhoof team with the elite contemporary classical outfit Ensemble Dal Niente for a weird and wonderful musical exchange.

title: The Stone Junction
label: Interscope
description: After a raft of free mixtapes and years after “Teach Me How To Jerk” blew up on MySpace, Audio Push return with their first for-sale release.

title: Lemonade
label: Columbia
description: Beyoncé is on a roll. Her latest, another "visual album" with corresponding videos in the mold of her 2013 self-titled set, renders infidelity and reconciliation with a cinematic vividness.

title: Double Ecstasy EP
label: Anticon
description: On his new EP, San Jose rapper Antwon raps about sex and drugs and general excess.

title: Always Strive and Prosper
label: RCA
description: Despite the strong production and features including Missy Elliott, Ty Dolla $ign, and Rick Ross, Ferg's latest is mainly about his wise observations on family, fame, and what comes next.

title: New Misery
label: Sub Pop
description: The lead singer of the now-defunct Smith Westerns steps out with a solo debut that furthers the emotional trajectory of his former band while offering a softer approach.

title: Delusions of Grand Fur
label: Easy Sound
description: On their new LP, California indie-poppers Rogue Wave hint at breaking open their songwriting model but keep things modest in the end.

title: At Last!
label: Jackpot Records
description: More than a half-century after its release, At Last! remains one of the greatest records about loneliness ever made: a languid, jazz-inflected paean to (reluctantly) working it out on your own.

title: Dolls of Highland
label: Sub Pop
description: Dolls of Highland melds the voodoo-infused mythology of the South with rambunctious glam rock, and Kyle Craft summons you into its world like a carnival barker wooing customers into a funhouse.

title: Too Many Voices
label: Modern Love
description: On his new album, Manchester producer Andy Stott is still dabbling in dark, abrasive textures while also moving towards something airier.

title: Bergtatt/Kveldssanger/Nattens Madrigal
label: Century Media
description: The first three albums by the Norwegian black metal band Ulver presaged the disintegration of heavy music's stylistic boundaries, laying the groundwork for everyone from Windhand to Deafheaven.

title: Rosecrans
label: EMPIRE
description: On a new shared EP, '90s G-funk legend DJ Quik and Problem, a rapper a generation younger, find a breezy, lazy rhythm together.

title: Some Other Time: the Lost Session from the Black Forest
label: Resonance
description: Some Other Time is a newly unearthed Bill Evans studio album, initially recorded in 1968 in Germany but not released until this month. It still sounds fresh and alive almost 50 years later.

title: Waltzed in from the Rumbling
label: Secret City
description: Plants and Animals may not have made their most original album with Waltzed in from the Rumbling, but they have definitely made their most beautiful one.

title: Lost Themes II
label: Sacred Bones
description: The legendary filmmaker and soundtrack composer John Carpenter began releasing standalone albums last year with Lost Themes. The followup is a reminder that the man was not known for sequels.

title: It Kindly Stopped for Me
label: Topshelf
description: Sorority Noise's hushed, brief EP is a four-song cycle about grief and loss, narrated from the perspectives of both the departed and those left behind.

title: Konono N°1 Meets Batida
label: Crammed Discs
description: The Congolese ensemble pairs with the Angolan-born producer Batida, and their best moments resemble a Ferris wheel spinning off its moorings, letting grooves careen and rumble as they might.

title: The Future of Death
label: Party Smasher Inc.
description: The Brooklyn quartet Primitive Weapons blend the all-out assault of hardcore with dexterity and melody, striking a balance of brains, brawn, and heart.

title: Blood Visions
label: Fat Possum
description: Jay Reatard was the kingpin of Memphis garage rock, and his best and most powerful full-length work—the record that made him a standalone rock star—was his first solo album.

title: Please Be Honest
label: Rockathon
description: On the 23rd album to bear the Guided By Voices name, the ageless and indefatigable Robert Pollard wrote every track and played every instrument himself.

title: Yoyogi Park
label: Mule Musiq
description: A wonderful, dreamy record of techno music that invites you to float freely in the time between late night and early morning. A perfect soundtrack for getting lost.

title: Tower of Meaning
label: Audika
description: The minimalist classical Tower of Meaning is the greatest outlier in Arthur Russell's recorded catalogue: the most uncharacteristic one-off project in a career that is full of them.

title: Phases
label: Manifesto
description: Cellars is the synth-pop project of Allene Norton. Her second album, produced by Ariel Pink, sounds zapped straight from the sepia-toned dance floor of a long-forgotten high school prom.

title: Music of Morocco: Recorded by Paul Bowles, 1959
label: Dust-to-Digital
description: This 4-disc box set, curated by legendary Beat Generation composer and writer Paul Bowles, offers an eye-opening and immersive introduction to Moroccan music.

title: BIS: 001-020
label: Beats in Space
description: BIS: 001-020 collects a track from each release on Tim Sweeney's Beats in Space label, making for a  groovy, lightly psychedelic compilation that might sound best at a deck party, or the beach.

title: The Diary
label: Mass Appeal
description: Just like any diamond unearthed after many years, J Dilla's long-lost solo album The Diary is flawed, but still precious.

title: Flutes, Echoes, It's All Happening!
label: Leaving
description: Carlos Niño's music charts an invisible continent where hippy jazz meets new age music and underground hip-hop meets airy, Laurel Canyon-style folk.

title: 印象III : なんとなく、パブロ (Imagining “The Life of Pablo”)
label: self-released
description: Toyomu is a Kyoto-based producer who assembled his own version of Kanye West's The Life of Pablo from online sources like Genius and WhoSampled when he couldn't stream it.

title: Become Alive
label: Other People
description: Before he became Nicolas Jaar’s foil in the electro-noir duo Darkside, guitarist Dave Harrington was immersed in the jazz world. Become Alive finds him circling back to his improv roots.

title: A Sailor's Guide to Earth
label: Atlantic
description: Progressive country's lead tastemaker changes his path again. A Sailor's Guide to Earth finds Sturgill Simpson weirder and more adventurous than ever, forging a bold new way forward.

title: Blind Spot EP
label: Edamame
description: Given all the recent shoegaze reunions—My Bloody Valentine, Slowdive—it makes sense Lush would make a comeback. Rather than simply embark on a nostalgia tour, Lush recorded this 4-song EP.

title: Missed Calls
label: Bad Habit
description: Tunji Ige, a 20-year-old Philadelphian son of Nigerian parents, makes appealingly low-stakes rap that accomplishes a lot with a little.

title: Welcome the Worms
label: Dead Oceans
description: L.A.-based quartet Bleached carve out a new identity on their latest, fast-forwaring past '60s revivalism into jagged and precise '70s rock edge.

title: Sleep Cycle
label: My Animal Home
description: Josh "Deakin" Dibb's  Sleep Cycle is a short album but a substantial one, a deeply personal work that takes us inside the mind of Animal Collective’s most mysterious member.

title: Don't Look Down
label: Mello Music Group
description: After a seven-year absence from rap, Mr. Lif returns with a sharp technical marvel of an album, and a meditation on all that’s brought him here.

title: Love Letter for Fire
label: Sub Pop
description: This slow-burning collaborative album from Jesca Hoop and Iron & Wine's Sam Beam recalls healing summer storms more than destructive blazes.

title: YYY EP
label: Arjunamusic
description: YYY is a collaboration between the minimalist techno of Tyler Friedman and the improvised jazz drumming of Samuel Rohrer, split across two long, flowing tracks.

title: Singing Saw
label: Dead Oceans
description: Kevin Morby (Woods, Babies) recalls singer/songwriters of the '60s and '70s in his solo work, particularly Bob Dylan and Leonard Cohen, and Singing Saw is his strongest album.

title: Crab Day
label: Drag City
description: On her fourth album, the Welsh singer Cate Le Bon establishes a strange, almost Dadaist lyrical scheme to make sense of some unnamed life rupture that's left her gasping.

title: Sorrow - A Reimagining of Gorecki's 3rd Symphony
label: 52Hz
description: Avant-garde saxophonist Colin Stetson's reimagining of the famous symphony by the Polish composer Henryk Gorecki comes close to something by Explosions in the Sky or Godspeed You! Black Emperor.

title: Layers
label: Bad Half Entertainment
description: Royce 5’9” has done his most visible rapping as a plus-one. Trying to move beyond that supporting role, he loads his sixth solo album with big-time producers, skits, and careful introspection.

title: Controlling Body
label: Peder Mannerfelt Produktion
description: The Swedish electronic musician Peder Mannerfelt, who has  produced groups like Fever Ray and Blonde Redhead, evokes a gothic energy in his own music. In his hands, electronic music's habitual futurism looks a lot more like horror.

title: Fever Dream
label: Caroline
description: Ben Watt's third solo album finds the Everything But the Girl co-founder continuing to explore his reignited love for live instrumentation.

title: Plays the Music of Twin Peaks
label: Polyvinyl / Bella Union
description: Xiu Xiu's tribute to the music of Twin Peaks is one of their most haunting and beautiful LPs in years.

title: The Hope Six Demolition Project
label: Island
description: On a fascinating and flawed new album, PJ Harvey yokes the siren-like catchiness of her last great America-influenced album, Stories From the City… to the swamp-tarnished filth of her classic first three records.

title: Year of the Rabbit
label: Double Double Whammy
description: Following on the heels of last year's O.K., the indie-pop outfit Eskimeaux releases a sweet little gem of an EP, fraught with indecision and insecurity.

title: Commitment to Complications
label: Dais Records
description: Commitment to Complications strikes the ideal balance between the visceral nature of the  innovative L.A. hardcore group Youth Code's demo and the polish in their work since then.

title: Outer Heaven
label: Carpark
description: The ferocious noise-punk quartet Greys redirects indie rock's inward gaze back out into the wider world.

title: Everybody's Heart Is Broken Now
label: Interscope
description: Niki and the Dove's Malin Dahlström has one of the most fantastic voices in pop, and on their new LP she whirls herself into a frenzy to nip malignant growths like heartache and hate in the bud.

title: Nat Love
label: Closed Sessions
description: On his new LP, Nat Love, rapper/singer/producer Kweku Collins offers intimate, hip-hop-informed bohemian rhapsodies.

title: Kill 'Em All/Ride the Lightning
label: self-released
description: In a monumental one-two punch, Metallica set the blueprint for thrash metal and then gave the genre its worldview with its first two records—reissued in deluxe sets that feature alternate mixes, demos, and live shows.

title: Ology
label: Mind of a Genius
description: Singer/songwriter Gallant's weightless voice channels ’80s and ’90s R&B, channeling the feeling of those eras without taking too much from them. On Ology, he’s coming to grips with all the struggle he’s endured, assessing himself through a mix of candor and ambiguity.

title: Standards
label: Triple Crown
description: Standards is Evan Weiss’ first Into It. Over It. album since he's turned 30. Often the eleoquent spokesperson for the emo revival, on Standards he banks on subtlety—as good a way as any to distinguish yourself in a scene defined by overstatement.

title: EARS
label: Western Vinyl
description: EARS, the rich and rewarding new album from composer Kaitlyn Aurelia Smith, is hard-to-pin-down music for the spaces in-between. In her hands, acoustic instruments sound like electronic ones, synthetic sounds reference nature, and human voices sound like the creation of machines.

title: Gore
label: Warner Bros.
description: Gore is easily Deftones’ most engaging record since White Pony, filled with carefully crafted hooks disguised as bridges and transition. As with all of their best music, it sounds like the brutal, beautiful result of the band being passionate enough to rip each other’s heads off.

title: Psychic Lovers
label: Captured Tracks
description: Singer/songwriter and producer Anders Rhedin is a former member of Choir of Young Believers, has written pop songs for Kid Cudi and Josh Groban, and has toured with Mac DeMarco under the Dinner alias. On his Captured Tracks debut, he offers a darkly deadpan take on ’80s synth-pop like the Simple Minds or Psychedelic Furs.

title: Junk
label: Mute
description: The new M83 album almost makes you wonder: How much can you mine vintage sounds without them finally falling apart?

title: Afterlife
label: Teklife
description: Afterlife compiles fifteen of DJ Rashad's previously unreleased collaborations. They match the mood and fervor you want from a Rashad track quite often, but it is hard to ignore their skeletal and fragmentary nature.

title: More Issues Than Vogue
label: Atlantic
description: Now best known as a reality star from "Love & Hip Hop," K. Michelle proves on her new release she's more than just two dimensional. More Issues Than Vogue is contemporary R&B at its best.

title: Azel
label: Partisan
description: Produced by Dirty Projectors leader Dave Longstreth, the virtuosic Saharan guitarist Bombino’s latest album features a sublime iteration of desert blues that’s both authentic and ambitious.

title: Painting of a Panic Attack
label: Canvasback / Atlantic
description: Formed in 2003, Frightened Rabbit established their reputation with ramshackle anthems of heartbreak and hangovers. With the National's Aaron Dessner behind the boards, their newest is more a sensible repositioning than a reinvention.

title: Atomic
label: Rock Action
description: Mogwai's latest full-length is technically a soundtrack, featuring reworked material from their musical contributions to a BBC 4 documentary on the atomic age.

title: Djungelns Lag/Mors Mors/Kom Tillsammans
label: Anthology Recordings
description: The music of ’70s Swedish group Träd, Gräs och Stenar (Trees, Grass, and Stones) emerged from a chemical reaction between two basic elements: rock'n'roll and Terry Riley.

title: Velvet Portraits
label: Ropeadope
description: Multi-instrumentalist Terrace Martin was a binding agent for Kendrick Lamar's last two releases; Velvet Portraits pulls in R&B and G-funk while paying homage to his native L.A.

title: Lost Time
label: Hardly Art
description: Tacocat's third album loses some of the brightness that helped make their pointed cultural critiques sound so impossibly fun.

title: Human Performance
label: Rough Trade
description: Parquet Courts' third album is a bracing snapshot of a band on a roll. Their music is not explicitly political, but Parquet Courts are definitely a thinking band, and a critical one.

title: Love Streams
label: 4AD
description: Love Streams marks a subtle shift in Tim Hecker's habitual style, a pivot away from his hazy trademark.

title: Interview 2016
label: Third Worlds
description: Interview 2016, another strange between-album release from Death Grips, is an intense instrumental EP that showcases the production chops of Zach Hill and Andy Morin.

title: Further / Chorus
label: Drag City
description: Bristol's Flying Saucer Attack were a murky and beloved cult band that mixed shoegaze guitars with the drifting throb of krautrock to create extreme feelings of isolation and alienation. These albums, now reissued on vinyl by Drag City, find them at the moment in the mid-'90s when their sound hit its stride.

title: City Sun Eater in the River of Light
label: Woodsist
description: After eight albums of solid if predictable psych-folk, Woods shake up their pastoral sound a bit, introducing notes of reggae and African jazz.

title: Twenty88
label: Def Jam
description: Twenty88 is the chosen name of the duo of rapper Big Sean and R&B singer Jhené Aiko. As a pair, they complement each other well, and the battle-of-the-sexes theme manages to work on the strength of their chemistry.

title: Halfaxa
label: Artbus Records
description: Claire Boucher's early experimentations were a far cry from the music she makes today. Halfaxa, 15 ethereal tracks in which her vocals approached pure glossolalia, is Grimes at her most mystical.

title: I AKA I
label: Ninja Tune
description: Tehran-via-London artist Ashkan Kooshanejad works by breaking down samples into unrecognizable blips of sound, and then layering them up into thickets of melody and rhythm.

title: Are You Serious
label: Loma Vista
description: Andrew Bird's latest release is his third album of pop originals since getting married and having a son, and a happy domesticity informs it.

title: It's the Big Joyous Celebration
label: Run for Cover
description: Teen Suicide is the old band of Sam Ray, whose other projects include Ricky Eat Acid and Julia Brown. He resurrected the band for a 26-track blowout of an album that is constantly absorbing and equal parts astonishing and frustrating.

title: Old Locks and Irregular Verbs
label: Pi Recordings
description: The veteran avant-garde jazz saxophonist and composer Henry Threadgill collaborates with pianist Jason Moran on his latest. The project offers plenty of room for twisty, adventurous solos, while also feeling like a tight 47 minutes.

title: Amen & Goodbye
label: Mute
description: Yeasayer's latest is an ambitious psychedelic quasi-concept record that is refreshingly (sometimes bizarrely) out-of-step with current trends, occasionally baffling, but mostly unsuccessful.

title: Patch the Sky
label: Merge
description: Bob Mould is at his best when he’s articulating anger at a high volume. His newest solo album, Patch the Sky, succeeds largely because these furious songs sound as if they're hardwired to raw nerves.

title: Pussy's Dead
label: Columbia
description: Autolux's third album is produced by Boots, and features a performance that permanently places Carla Azar amongst the pantheon of great American rock drummers.

title: Everything You've Come to Expect
label: Domino
description: The long-awaited second album from the Last Shadow Puppets  is a lavish California confection, with strings by Owen Pallett. Like Zayn Malik's Mind of Mine, it makes very clear that frontmen Alex Turner and Miles Kane are sexy men with sexy lives having lots of sexy sex with their sexy girlfriends.

title: Sept. 5th
label: Warner Bros.
description: On their debut album, the elusive R&B act signed to Drake's OVO Sound treats sex not as a social transaction but a serious act—something that can make you see things that aren't there, that can be a balm for life's rough edges, that can show you the worth of looking beyond yourself.

title: All Empires Fall
label: Relapse
description: The Brooklyn metal band Tombs have shifted their lineup repeatedly while maintaining an eerie consistency—the group hasn’t released a bad record. Their new EP is capable of making you think of Unsane, Darkthrone, and Bauhaus in the same song.

title: Rojus
label: Running Back
description: The British house producer Leon Vynehall's new album continues in the vein of 2014's mini-LP Music for the Uninvited, but it boasts a bigger sound in almost every way, with more layers, bolder basslines, and harder-edged drums.

title: Super
label: x2
description: The Pet Shop Boys have persisted long enough that their return to club music feels calmly liberated, without any grasping for pop hits. On their latest, Super, they recall their own past with trademark arch wit.

title: The Follower
label: Kompakt
